cab.content: IThin Document is the Property of His Britannic majesty's government!Printed for the War Cabinet. November 1918.SECRET.NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION-No. 78.Week ended l&h November, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS. On 10th November, at 2 p.m., the paddle minesweeper " Ascot," when 5 miles East North Seajof Fame Islands, was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine. The whole of the crew comprising 5 officers and 47 men were lost. On 11th November, at 3.30 p.m., a German submarine fired a torpedo at the Destroyer" Moy," off Coquet Island, but missed her. On 12th November the Allied Fleet passed through the Dardanelles, arriving off Mediter-Constantinople at 8 a.m. the following day. ranean. On 14th November the cruiser " Cochrane " grounded at the entrance to the Mersey. Casualty.Efforts to float the vessel have so far been unsuccessful, and as her condition is considered to be critical, the turret guns have been removed and all ammunition has been disembarked. The only submarine activity experienced during the week was in the North Sea where, Submarinesas above stated, an enemy submarine sunk a paddle minesweeper and unsuccessfully operating.attacked a destroyer. No attacks were made during the week upon merchant vessels and no enemy sub-marines are known to have been destroyed. The Merchant Vessels lost by mine during the week under review were one British Vessels lost.steamship of 1,721 tons which struck a British mine in the Straits of Dover, and oneNorwegian steamship of 1,208 tons which was mined in the North Sea. (C 1539) Wt. - 50 11/18 H&SENEMY SUBMARINES.MERCANTILE LOSSES BY MINE. Mine-iaying. ENEMY MINES.No enemy minelaying activity is reported during the week under review.Casualties. The following Table shows the number of enemy mines destroyed in British mine- sweeping areas and of British vessels sunk by enemy mines in recent weeks : Week Ended. Number of Enemy Moored Mines Destroyed. Number of British Mine-sweepers and Patrols Sunk by Mines. Number of British Merchant Steamships Sunk by Mines. Home Waters (including Ostend and Zeebrugge). Abroad. Oct. 19th ...... 26th ...... Nov. 2nd ...... 9th ...... 16th ...... 3 70 10 16 31 1 Nil 5 10 5 Nil 1 Nil Nil 2 Nil 1 Nil Nil Nil Of the mines stated above to have been destroyed this week, 3 were accounted forin an old area off the west coast of Ireland, 28 off the Belgian coast and 5 off Port Said.In addition, about 100 mines have been swept up in the Dardanelles from minefields laidboth by the Allies and the enemy. The vessels mined during the week were the Minesweeper "Ascot" before referredto and the trawler " Renarro," which was lost in the Dardanelles.NAVAL STAFF, 21st November, 1918. NOTE. It is intended that this should be the last NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION unless there is a further outbreak of hostilities at sea, but a final Appreciation recording thelast stages of the war at sea and the carrying out of the Naval Terms of Armistice willbe prepared and circulated in due course.
